0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Hereditary angioedema, Acute Attacks: 30 mg SUBQ in three 10-mg (1-mL) injections; an additional dose of 30 mg may be administered within a 24-hour period if attack persists

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: Hereditary angioedema, Acute Attacks: (12 years or older) 30 mg SUBQ in three 10-mg (1-mL) injections; an additional dose of 30 mg may be administered within a 24-hour period if attack persists

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Subcutaneous (Solution)
Anaphylaxis has been reported after administration of ecallantide. Because of this risk, ecallantide should only be administered by a healthcare professional who is aware of the similarity of symptoms between anaphylaxis and hereditary angioedema and who has the appropriate medical support to manage both conditions. Patients should be monitored closely.

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis, have been reported and occurred within the first hour after dosing; monitoring recommended
  • report suspected adverse reactions to Dyax Corp. at 1-888-452-5248 or the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (3% to 7.4%), Pruritus (5.1%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (5.1%), Diarrhea (4% to 10.6%), Nausea (5% to 12.9%), Vomiting (5.5%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (8% to 16.1%)
  • Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (3% to 5.9%), Respiratory tract infection (8.2%)
  • Other:Fatigue (11.8%)
Serious
Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (2.7% to 3.9%), Hypersensitivity reaction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Ecallantide, a human plasma kallikrein inhibitor, is a potent, selective, reversible inhibitor of plasma kallikrein. Ecallantide binds to plasma kallikrein and blocks its binding site, inhibiting the conversion of high molecular weight (HMW) kininogen to bradykinin. By directly inhibiting plasma kallikrein, it reduces the conversion of HMW kininogen to bradykinin. Because excessive bradykinin is thought to be responsible for the characteristic hereditary angioedema (HAE) symptoms (localized swelling, inflammation, and pain), ecallantide treats symptoms of acute episodic attacks of HAE by reducing excessive bradykinin generation.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Subcutaneous
  • 3 vials are required for 1 total dose
  • withdraw liquid from vial using a large bore needle; change to suitable needle (27 gauge) prior to administration
  • administer subQ into the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm; separate sites by at least 2 inches and away from anatomical site of attack; site rotation not necessary

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• symptomatic improvement
  • symptoms of hypersensitivity reaction, particularly within the first hour after administration

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug may cause hypersensitivity reactions, headache, nausea, diarrhea, fatigue, fever, and nasopharyngitis.
  • Advise patient to report injection site reactions that are bothersome, such as erythema, itching, pain, irritation, urticaria, and bruising.
